university.title: Queen's Buildings
university.description:
The Queen's Buildings house the Schools of Physics and Astronomy and Engineering which facilitate multidisciplinary collaboration. They also house a restaurant, coffee shop and award-winning library.

Water refill locations:

West Building, Forum - Near Plant Room W/1.13A
West Building Extension, ground floor - 0.03
West Building Extension, first floor - 1.03
West Building Extension, second floor - 2.03
West Building Extension, third floor - 3.01

university.title: Main Building (Park Place)
university.description:
Main Building - Architect W.D. Caroe sought to combine the charm and elegance of his former college (Trinity College, Cambridge) with the picturesque balance of many of the University of Oxford colleges. Building work on the Main Building commenced in 1905 and was completed in many stages, the first in 1909. Money ran short for this project, however, and although the side-wings were completed in the 1960s the planned Great Hall has never been built.

Water refill locations: 

Ground floor - North corridor next to 0.91
Ground floor - 0.45 next to sink in PVC suite
1st floor - Opposite Council Chamber by library

university.title: Tower Building
university.description:
The reception desk opposite the main entrance is fitted with an induction loop for people with hearing impairments. There are two lifts that service all floors in the Tower Building, however there is restricted access to the first and second floors. A key will be issued at reception to access these floors.

The Tower refectory is located on the ground floor, opposite the main entrance. There is a shop with a seating area and computers are available for internet access.

Accessible gender-neutral toilets are located on the ground and third floors. Toilet 0.06, on the ground floor is situated to the left of the main entrance, through the motorised double doors. The third floor toilet is room number 3.06.

university.title: Main Hospital Building
university.address: University Hospital of Wales, Heath Park

university.title: Music Building
university.description: As you approach the School of Music, you can’t fail to notice the bronze sculpture on the lawn outside. We often get asked about this artwork so here’s a little background on it. The piece is called Three Obliques (Walk-In) and was created by the famed artist Dame Barbara Hepworth in 1968. Only two others exist, one at Chatsworth House, and one in Seattle. It’s an astonishing piece of sculpture and provides a lovely backdrop for our annual graduation photos!

university.title: Bute Building
university.description:
This Grade II listed neoclassical building was designed by architects Percy Thomas and Ivor Jones, who won a competition in 1911 to design a building for Cardiff Technical College. The foundations of the building were laid in 1913 and the building opened in 1916. There are six Roman Doric columns in the front of the building.

Water refill locations:

Lower Floor 
- Room -1.12a male toilets 

1st Floor 
- Outside the library 

Ground Floor
- Refectory Area

university.title: Law and Politics Building
university.description:
Accessibility information
There is level access into the Law Building from Park Place and access from Museum Place is via a ramp with handrails or 5 steps with a handrail on the left hand side.

The reception is fitted with an induction loop for people with a hearing impairment. The lift services all floors, has a fold down seat for people with a mobility impairment, a mirror at the back and the levels are both audio and visually indicated.

There are accessible cubicles in the male (0.21) and female toilets (0.23) on the ground floor. There is an accessible gender-neutral toilet on the first floor (1.25A), which is around the corner from the lift.

university.title: Hadyn Ellis Building
university.description:
The Hadyn Ellis building is named in honour of the late University Deputy Vice-Chancellor, Professor Hadyn Ellis. The ground floor includes an attractive public area for lectures, displays and conferences about the University’s work and a 150-person lecture theatre. The building has been recognised for its sustainability and was awarded the Higher Education category of the Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method BREEAM) Awards Wales in 2012.

university.title: Talybont South
university.description: Talybont South is part of the Talybont complex which is the largest of the University’s residences and provides a range of social amenities including excellent sports facilities. This purpose-built development is situated close to large areas of parkland and is a short walk or cycle to most of the academic buildings.

university.title: Aberdare Hall
university.description: Aberdare Hall was built in 1893 and retains many interesting period features. It is adjacent to the Cathays Park campus and offers both part catered and self catered accommodation. During term-time, the part catered option provides breakfast and evening meals Monday to Friday.

university.title: Talybont Court
university.description: Talybont Court is part of the Talybont complex, which is the largest of the University’s residences and provides a range of social amenities including excellent sports facilities. university.title: Senghennydd Hall
university.description: Senghennydd Hall is a part catered residence situated within a very short distance of the Cathays Park campus and ideal for students studying Mathematics, Physics and Astronomy, Engineering or Computer Science. The evening meal service provides students with a hot meal Monday to Friday except during vacations. Generally the meals are served 17:00-20:00 at the nearby Trevithick Restaurant in the Queen's Buildings.

university.title: School of Journalism, Media and Culture, No 2 Central Square
university.description: The School of Journalism, Media and Culture is located opposite Cardiff Central Train Station and is approximately 20-30 minutes on foot from the Cathays Park Campus. If you are travelling by train, you may wish to plan your day in advance and consider visiting the School on arrival at Cardiff Central, or on your return to the station.

university.title: Centre for Student Life
university.description:
The Centre for Student Life is a service-led project delivered in partnership with the Students’ Union and is part of the biggest campus upgrade in a generation. It is the fruition of a successful and dynamic partnership that the University is proud to enjoy with its student body.

The new building is home to the University's Student Life services including support with study, health and wellbeing, preparing for the future, managing money and living in Cardiff. It will also increase links with the Students’ Union and enhance the services already provided there.

Water refill locations:

Ground floor - North end of the building
1st floor - North end of the building
2nd floor - North end of the building
3rd floor - North end of the building
4th floor - North end of the building

university.title: Abacws Building
university.description:
Accessibility information

There is level access into Abacws from Senghennydd Road through the main entrance, and also from the rear of the building behind Cathays train station.

The lifts service all floors. Each lift has a mirror at the back and the levels are both audio and visually indicated.

There are two accessible cubicles on each floor. These are adjacent to each set of toilets.

Baby changing facilities are available in the Toilet for All on the ground floor.

Parking

There is street parking along Senghennydd Road, where blue badge holders can park free of charge.

Bicycle Parking

There are also freely available bicycle racks to the rear of the building next to the Cathays railway station ticket office.

Water refill locations:

2nd floor - North corridor
2nd floor - South corridor
3rd floor - North corridor
3rd floor - South corridor
4th floor - South corridor
5th floor - North corridor

transportation.title: By car
transportation.description:
Please note we are unable to offer parking on University premises, with the exception of a limited number of spaces in Bute Building car park for visitors with a disability. Please contact us in advance if you require this (openday@cardiff.ac.uk). 

However, there is limited on street ‘pay and display’ parking on Park Place, Senghennydd Road and within the civic centre. This typically costs around £8 for five hours. Charges for city centre multi-storey car parks vary considerably, up to approximately £32.95 per day.

**Due to a concert at Blackweir Fields on Friday 27 June, there will be road closures in the vicinity of our campus from 16:00. All day event parking will be enforced around the Civic Centre at a charge of £20 per car.**

transportation.title: Cardiff Bus, Cardiff East Park & Ride
transportation.description:
Park & Ride, Junction 30 of the A48 (M), CF23 8HH

There will be a special University Open Day shuttle service from the Cardiff East Park and Ride (Junction 30 of the A48(M), CF23 8HH) site to our Cathays Park Campus. The Open Day bus service begins after 08:00 and runs until 16:30.

Buses from the Park and Ride depart approximately every 15 minutes. The journey time to the city centre is around 20 minutes and will cost £12 per car (cash or contactless). If paying by cash, the exact fare is required. The Park and Ride service may provide a more convenient option as spaces in the city centre can be limited and the cost of parking can vary.

Return buses to the Cardiff East Park and Ride site will depart from the bus stop outside the Law Building on Park Place (Cathays Park Campus) throughout the day, until 16:30. This is the same bus stop at which visitors disembark the shuttle service on the inbound journey.

**Please note that, at peak times, there may be a queue on both the inbound and outbound route. The Park and Ride site closes promptly at 18:00 and is locked overnight. It will not be possible to access the site after 18.00 and the site remains closed on Sundays.**

transportation.title: Cardiff Central Train Station
transportation.description:
Frequent regional network trains connect Cardiff with many towns and cities across the UK. Cardiff Central train station is approximately 20 minutes’ walk from Cardiff University's Main Building. Walking will allow you to get a feel for the city including the shops, restaurants and entertainment it has to offer.


Given the School of Journalism, Media and Culture's close proximity to Cardiff Central Train Station, those travelling by train who are interested in Journalism courses may wish to consider visiting the School on arrival to Cardiff or on their return to the station. Please consult the School's pages in the app to see their scheduled activities.

transportation.title: Cardiff Airport
transportation.description:
Several inter-regional and international air services operate from Cardiff Airport, which is about 12 miles from the city centre. Find out more about public transport links to and from Cardiff International Airport by visiting the airport's website. 

Additional transport services are available from a number of UK airports providing onwards travel to Cardiff.

transportation.title: Cathays Train Station
transportation.description: Visitors can change at Cardiff Central for Cathays Train Station. Cathays station is located in the centre of the Cathays Park Campus, opposite the Main Building. It provides easy access to all other University buildings at Cathays Park Campus, including the Students’ Union.

transportation.title: By car
transportation.description:
Please note we are unable to offer parking on University premises, with the exception of a limited number of spaces for visitors with a disability. Please contact us in advance if you require this (+44 (0)29 2087 4455). 

However, there is limited on street ‘pay and display’ parking on Park Place, Senghennydd Road and within the civic centre. This typically costs around £6.60 for five hours. Charges for city centre multi-storey car parks vary considerably, up to approximately £30 per day.

transportation.title: By bus
transportation.description: National coach companies, such as National Express and Megabus, run regular services to Cardiff from many major cities across the UK. Our main coach station is based at Sophia Gardens. However, we advise that you check the departure and arrival points with each individual operator.
